Description: Fragment of solid-cast amuletic figure of the god Harpokrates in copper alloy; god represented as naked male child, slightly bent or seated with left arm by his side and right arm broken (originally god holding his finger to his mouth?); wearing sidelock of youth to the right side of his head; broken below thighs; remains of loop at back (might have been used as an amulet); simplistic and flat rendering; corroded.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Bolton Museum. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Bronze figures of Harpokrates were common during the Late and Ptolemaic periods in Egypt and particularly in the Delta (Sandri 2006; Weiss 2012, 126-157, Typ 41-69, Pl. 11-19). Likewise, the child deity was very popular in Naukratis. He appears in a large number of small votives and amuletic figures, in a variety of materials and shapes (Masson forthcoming).
